title: 108_s1646
content: The "Transportation Safety Program Extension Act of 2003" is cited as the short title. The Act extends the motor carrier safety program. The Highway Trust Fund provides $119,125,000 for motor carrier safety programs, research, and border enforcement activities. This includes funding for State border safety inspection facilities and regulatory development. The Motor Carrier Safety Account is established in the Treasury for regulatory development. The Secretary of Transportation can make grants to states only if they maintain their expenditures at a certain level. Funds can be used for obligations similar to those under title 23 of the United States Code. SEC. 3. Extension of motor carrier safety assistance program. The Motor Carrier Safety Assistance Program is amended to allocate $77,125,000 for the period from October 1, 2003, to February 29, 2004. Additionally, $8,333,000 is designated for Information Systems during the same period. The Secretary of Transportation is authorized to grant funds to states for maintenance of expenditures. The Motor Carrier Safety Assistance Program authorizes grants to states for maintenance of expenditures, requiring states to maintain spending levels equal to the average of the last 2 fiscal years before October 1, 2003. SEC. 4. EXTENSION OF HIGHWAY SAFETY PROGRAMS. The Highway Safety Programs under the Transportation Equity Act of the 21st Century are amended to allocate additional funds for the period from October 1, 2003, to February 29, 2004. This includes adjustments for Highway Safety Research and Development, as well as Occupant Protection Incentive Grants. Incentive Grants for Alcohol-Impaired Driving Counter-Measures program under the Transportation Equity Act of the 21st Century is extended with additional funding of $16,640,000 for the period from October 1, 2003, to February 29, 2004. The National Driver Register funding is amended for the period from October 1, 2003, to February 29, 2004, with an additional $1,498,000 allocated. The applicability of Title 23 is also updated to reflect the year 2004. SEC. 5. Extension of sport fishing and boating safety program. Section 13106 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allocate $2,083,333 from the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act for Coast Guard expenses related to the national recreational boating safety program. $833,333 is specifically designated for ensuring compliance with chapter 43 of this title. No funds can be used to replace traditional funding sources. The funds allocated under this section cannot replace traditional funding sources and must be used for authorized purposes only. The funds will remain available until expended, and the Secretary is required to provide an annual detailed report on the projects, programs, and activities funded.
